articles.title: Arnaud Natal
articles.contents:
Home
          
          
          
          
          
          ☰
          
          
      
        
          
            
              
            
              Arnaud Natal
            
            
              
                
                    
                      
                        CV
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                        Research
                      
                    
                  
                                  
            
          
        
        
        
          
            
            Welcome to my page!
            I am a PhD student at the Economics department (BSE) of the
            University of Bordeaux in France and affiliated with the French Institute of
            Pondicherry (IFP) in India. I am also involved in the Observatory of Rural
            Dynamics and Inequalities in South India (ODRIIS), and I
            am a member of the AFEDEV.
            Data I am working on (from collection to analysis) are
            now freely available on Harvard
            Dataverse.
            My main field of interest is development economics, and I
            work on topics related to household indebtedness, labour,
            and cognition in rural India.
            Networks: Google
            Scholar | ORCID |
            Research
            Gate | GitHub | Repec | IdHAL | Linkedin
            Contact:  BSE UMR-CNRS 6060, 
            Université de Bordeaux,  16 Avenue Léon Duguit, 
            33608 PESSAC CEDEX, FRANCE. arnaud.natal@u-bordeaux.fr

articles.title: Research
articles.description:
My research mobilises statistical tools to analyse the financial behaviour, labour and cognition of households in rural South India.
I pay particular attention to the quality of the data, the transparency of the analyses and the ethics of research more generally.
I am also involved in the [NEEMSIS](https://neemsis.hypotheses.org/) data collection.

Contents
Working
papers
Publications in
peer-reviewed journals
In progress
Data

Working papers
Ten years of labour, migration and debt in India: Insights from
original longitudinal household surveys in Tamil Nadu, with M. Di
Santolo, I. Guérin, S. Michiels, C. Mouchel, C.J. Nordman & G.
Venkatasubramanian.
Hard Times: Measure and Analysis of Household’s Financial
Vulnerability in Rural South India.
She Works Hard for the Money: Financial Vulnerability and Labour
Supply in Rural South India.
A Change is Gonna Come: Measures and Stability of Personality
Traits in Rural South India, with C.J. Nordman.
Psychology of Debt in Rural South India, with C.J.
Nordman.
Publications in
peer-reviewed journals
Surviving Debt, Survival Debt in Times of Lockdown. Economic
& Political Weekly, 57(1), 41–49, with I. Guérin, S. Michiels,
C.J. Nordman, & G. Venkatasubramanian, G. (2022). Full article
available here.
Locus of Control, Social Identity, and Indebtedness in South India.
Revue d’Économie du Développement, 31(2-3), 95-101, with C.J.
Nordman. (2022).
In progress
The Political and Sexual Economies of Marriages: Two Decades of
change in South-Arcot, South India, with I. Guérin, C.J. Nordman
& G. Venkatasubramanian.
Individual Debt Traps: Insights from Rural Tamil Nadu.
Data
Network
Employment dEbt, Mobilities and Skills in south Indian Survey
(NEEMSIS)
NEEMSIS is a socio-economic panel survey conducted in rural Tamil
Nadu with two data points: 2016-17 and 2020-21. The NEEMSIS survey aim
at understanding the links between labour, skills, social and migration
dynamics and social networks formation in India. It explores how the
formation of skills and social networks, especially those defined at the
community and individual levels, influence observed inequalities in
individuals’ trajectories in terms of social status (class, caste,
gender, ethnicity, religion), employment and migration. This includes
the investigation of various forces at play, spanning from the role of
social structure (norms and institutions), the development and use of
social networks, to the formation of cognitive and non-cognitive skills.
You can find more information on the NEEMSIS website.
Nordman, C. J., Guérin, I., Venkatasubramanian, G., Michiels, S.,
Lanos, Y., Hilger, A., Kumar, S., Raj, A., & Natal, A. (2023).
NEEMSIS-1 wave data (data). Harvard Dataverse. https://doi.org/10.7910/DVN/KN3KFJ
RUral
Microfinance and Employment survey (RUME)
RUME survey is a socio-economic survey conducted in rural Tamil Nadu
in 2010, in 10 villages and 405 households. The main objective was to
explore the linkages between rural finance and rural employment –
including diversification and migration – with a view to contributing to
the ongoing discussions and interventions in the fields of rural
development and poverty and vulnerability reduction. You can find more
information on the RUME
website.
Guérin, I., Venkatasubramanian, G., Michiels, S., Roesch, M., &
Natal, A. (2023). RUME survey data (data). Harvard Dataverse.
https://doi.org/10.7910/DVN/2KVFXG
